Award.AwardTitle: Magnetic resonance imaging and spectroscopy at the nanoscale via probe paramagnetic centers
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program, Carlos A. Meriles of the City University of New York (City College) is developing magnetic resonance imaging, or MRI, techniques for a variety of materials, including living tissue, with much higher resolution than is currently available. MRI is a well-known technique in diagnostic medicine but it is limited in the size of structures within the body that can be visualized. Recent advances have made it possible to visualize small organelles within individual cells, but the ability to probe within these organelles still eludes researchers. This project seeks to refine MRI in order to acquire sharp images of ever-smaller objects without going to invasive means. The research is focused on the development of a new type of probe for the MRI device. The probe, consisting of a tiny tip that can be hovered over the sample being studied, is coated with a special kind of diamond in which two adjacent carbon atoms have been removed. A nitrogen atom replaces one of these carbons, but the other is left as an empty hole. The resulting defect, known as a nitrogen vacancy, or NV, defect, responds to variations in the sample being studied by changing the way it spins. The change in spin direction can be detected by light that is emitted from this tip after it has been illuminated by a laser. The emitted light is stronger if the NV center spins around an axis pointing up, but it is weaker if the spin is around an axis pointing down toward the sample. The difference in emitted light in different parts of the sample can be fed into a computer and converted into an image that has a much higher resolution than current MRI images. It is possible that one day this technique may even allow scientists to visualize single atoms within large biological molecules such as proteins. This work is, thus, having a broad impact through the development of tools that will find wide applicability in biological science and medicine. It is having a further broad impact through the development of opportunities for underprivileged students to participate in this research through summer activities at the City College of New York as well as in the host laboratories of partner institutions.

The project addresses a current limitation of MRI by exploring a new modality of spin sensing at the nanoscale via the use of a nitrogen vacancy (NV) centers in diamond. Rather than detecting single spins, the strategy focuses on the case where the NV center interacts with small ensembles of spins localized over effective volumes of about a hundred cubic nanometers. Building on the group's recent observation of proton spin noise at the nanoscale, the current goal is to advance NV-based spin sensing via new protocols designed to enhance the information content of the observed signals and broaden the technique's applicability to a more general class of samples. The work has two main thrusts: (1) The first thrust area uses near-surface NVs to probe model sample systems on the diamond surface whose molecular dynamics is changed by inducing a controlled phase transition or by restricting diffusion. Various magnetic resonance schemes are being implemented so as to expose the composition, mobility and, if possible, the structure of the sample molecules via spectroscopic signatures. (2) The second main thrust involves a shift in emphasis from nanoscale spectroscopy to nanoscale imaging via a geometry based on an NV-hosting scanning tip. A unique set of high-purity diamond nanopillars produced via top-down nanofabrication is being combined with an AFM-confocal system to demonstrate T1-weighted spin imaging with nanoscale spatial resolution. Since the presence of additional paramagnetic defects in the diamond host is not necessarily detrimental to sensing, the work has another goal, closely related to the first, to explore alternate protocols conceived to initialize and control the spin bath in a broad set of engineered nanocrystals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the last decade, color centers in gemstones - crystal imperfections in the form of impurities and/or empty lattice sites - have attracted widespread attention for new forms of sensing at the nanoscale, often benefiting from the quantum properties of these defects. Among them, the so-called nitrogen-vacancy (NV) center has emerged as one of the most appealing because it can be addressed individually using existing confocal microscopy techniques. Further, it features a magnetic moment (or 'spin') whose orientation can be initialized, manipulated, and ultimately detected via the use of pulse protocols combining visible light and low-frequency microwave excitation. Therefore, when sufficiently close to the diamond surface, the NV can serve as a local probe to gather information on the structure, dynamics, and composition of nearby samples with nanoscale precision. 

Throughout this project, our work introduced and demonstrated new nanoscale sensing strategies that have been extensively used by us and other groups throughout the world, with some recent adaptations being applied to nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy of mass limited compounds. We also developed new forms of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that extended its applicability to areas seemingly beyond its traditional boundaries, including, for example, the measurement of local thermal conductivity with 10 nm precision. 

Since the spin of the NV can be polarized (i.e., aligned) almost perfectly with the help of only mild illumination, we also developed techniques of polarization transfer to systems (e.g., fluids) that cannot be optically spin pumped. Because the operating conditions (room temperature, low magnetic fields) are substantially simpler than the most popular techniques in use today (relying on complex high-frequency microwave generators and cryogenic instrumentation), the route we pursued promises to revolutionize the capabilities of NMR through the use of bench-top, portable instrumentation of widespread access and low cost.

One of the fascinating aspects of the NV is that not only its spin but also its charge (changing from negative to neutral) can be altered with the help of optical pulses of suitable duration, wavelength, and amplitude. Through careful studies with variable-concentration ensembles of shallow NVs, we learned that surface proximity dramatically alters the dynamics of NV ionization and recombination, possibly due to the presence of surface traps and concomitant new charge transfer channels not allowed to bulk NVs. These observations point to NV-charge-based (as opposed to NV-spin-based) sensing as an alternative tool for nanoscale sensing, that can be exploited, for example, to probe electro-chemical activity and/or ionic transport near the diamond surface.

Finally, we applied the lessons we learned on the charge dynamics of NVs to understand the properties of a new class of color centers, this time confined within hexagonal boron nitride (hBN). Similar to diamond, hBN has a wide bandgap (i.e., is transparent) and can thus host potentially valuable color centers; however, being isomorphic to graphene (a 2D material), it can be produced in the form of single- or few-atomic-layer films. Through this project, we demonstrated the ability to spatially 'activate' hBN-hosted color centers into a fluorescent state simply by shaping the substrate to introduce local strain in the overlaid hBN film. The underlying mechanism of this phenomenon was understood in terms of a strain-induced electric potential, able to trap electrical carriers and thus selectively alter the color center charge state in the immdiate vicinity from dark to bright. Given the ability to pick and place single- or few-atomic-layer hBN flakes on arbitrary structures, our studies open the door to charge-based sensing modalities that rely on material platforms other than diamond.

The different forms of nanoscale sensing our work has helped develop promise new opportunities for investigating the physical chemistry and dynamics of compounds at the interface with solids, difficult (if not impossible) to investigate via alternative means. By the same token, NV-driven dynamic nuclear polarization has the potential to open new areas of NMR applicability (that benefit from the low-cost and compact blueprint of the required instrumentation), and profoundly impact all other fields where magnetic resonance is already used (ranging from the food and pharmaceutical industries, to medical and biological science, to well logging among many others),
